abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project is assessed to have
            achieved a satisfactory outcome; project sustainability is
            likely. IDA performance is rated satisfactory and Borrower
            performance is rated as highly satisfactory. Five key
            lessons from this project have been taken into consideration
            by follow-on projects. First, long-term loans to poor
            villages can complement village resources to sustainably and
            significantly improve water supply. The project demonstrates
            that government capital subsidies can be substantially lower
            than typically argued for when discussing improved rural
            water for the poor. Second, demand for improved latrines is
            correlated with higher income levels, and, in contrast to
            improved water supply, the income levels of the rural poor
            in this project were too low to support the latrine
            improvement strategy. Third, investing in model villages is
            not a successful strategy for yielding demonstration effects
            when the external government financing needed to construct
            the model is unavailable to other villages seeking to
            replicate the model. Fourth, training of water plant
            managers, operators, and accountants is critical to the
            sustainability of the water plant subprojects and Credit
            proceeds should be made available to ensure that adequate
            training occurs. Fifth, in order to increase the acceptance
            of health messages and encourage behavior modification,
            inhibitors to improving practice must be identified and the
            health education program refined accordingly.
